Later that day, The Bodhisatta returned to find the disheveled, featherless Crow whimpering in the corner, his spirit broken and his body aching. "So, my friend," The Pigeon observed, his voice tinged with both sorrow and irony, "it seems the serpent of greed has indeed brought you sorrow. How do those stolen delights taste now?" With that final, broken admission, the life ebbed from the Greedy Crow, his ignoble end a stark lesson on the perils of avarice.
